title: 112_s3218
content:
The Small Business Export Growth Act of 2012 is the short title of the act. It aims to improve coordination of export promotion programs. The Small Business Export Growth Act of 2012 focuses on improving coordination of export promotion programs, including consolidating duplicative activities, clarifying roles of committee members, and enhancing Export.gov as a single window for export information. It also aims to facilitate export opportunities for small businesses. The Small Business Export Growth Act of 2012 includes provisions for promoting exporting, small business export matchmaking, export control education, inter-agency task force on export financing, and availability of State resource guides on Export.gov. It also focuses on consolidating duplicative export promotion activities and providing information about trade missions and trade fairs. The Small Business Export Growth Act of 2012 aims to promote exporting, small business export matchmaking, export control education, and inter-agency coordination. It includes provisions for consolidating export promotion activities and providing information on trade missions and fairs. Amendments to the Export Enhancement Act of 1988 focus on identifying opportunities for office consolidation and resource allocation, as well as enhancing electronic database coordination for trade activities. The Small Business Export Growth Act of 2012 aims to promote exporting, small business export matchmaking, export control education, and inter-agency coordination. It includes provisions for consolidating export promotion activities and providing information on trade missions and fairs. The Act also requires the Secretary of Commerce to make available detailed listings of current and future Federal and State-led trade missions, trade fairs, and related activities on Export.gov or a successor website. SEC. 102 clarifies the roles of members of the Trade Promotion Coordinating Committee. Section 2312(c) of the Export Enhancement Act of 1988 is amended to clarify the roles and objectives of each department or agency that is a member of the TPCC, including the need to measure and report on goals. Congress is also included in the oversight of export promotion and financing activities. The Export Enhancement Act of 1988 is amended to clarify the roles and objectives of TPCC members, including measuring and reporting on goals. Congress is involved in oversight, and recommendations from the Comptroller General are included for coordination. The United States National Tourism Organization is replaced by the United States Travel Association. SEC. 103 amends the Export Enhancement Act of 1988 to include a representative of state agencies on the Trade Promotion Coordinating Committee. SEC. 104 requires reports to Congress regarding the activities of the TPCC. Section 2312(f) of the Export Enhancement Act of 1988 is amended to require the chairperson of the TPCC to submit an annual report to Congress by March 30. The report should include details on the strategic plan, its implementation, revisions, funding for export promotion activities, and the interagency working groups on energy. Additionally, the inspector general of the Department of Commerce is also required to submit reports to Congress. The Inspector General of the Department of Commerce prepares and submits an annual report to Congress by March 30 on the TPCC's duties and the successful implementation of the strategic plan. The Inspector General of the Department of Commerce consults with other federal agencies in implementing subsection (c) successfully. Appropriate congressional committees are defined in this subsection. The appropriate congressional committees consulted by the Inspector General include the Senate's Commerce, Finance, Foreign Relations, Small Business and Entrepreneurship committees, and the House's Appropriations, Energy and Commerce, Financial Services, Foreign Affairs, Small Business, and Ways and Means committees. SEC. 105. REPORT ON IMPROVEMENTS TO EXPORT.GOV AS A SINGLE WINDOW FOR EXPORT INFORMATION. The Director of International Trade of the Small Business Administration will submit a report to Congress within 180 days of this Act's enactment, with recommendations for enhancing Export.gov as a comprehensive resource for exporters to submit required information to the Federal Government. A single website for exporters to submit all required information to the Federal Government is established. Entities specified include small business concerns that are exporters, the President's Export Council, State agencies, district export councils, and trade associations. SEC. 106. REPORT ON DEVELOPING A SINGLE WINDOW FOR INFORMATION ABOUT EXPORT CONTROL COMPLIANCE. The Chief Counsel for Advocacy of the Small Business Administration must submit a report to congressional committees within 180 days of this Act's enactment, evaluating the benefits of creating a website as a comprehensive resource for complying with U.S. export control laws and regulations, and as a single platform for exporters to submit required information to the Federal Government. The term "appropriate congressional committees" refers to specific Senate and House committees. The term "appropriate congressional committees" refers to specific Senate and House committees: the Committee on Commerce, Science, and Transportation, the Committee on Small Business and Entrepreneurship in the Senate, and the Committee on Energy and Commerce, the Committee on Small Business in the House of Representatives. TITLE II--FACILITATION OF EXPORT OPPORTUNITIES FOR SMALL BUSINESSES

SEC. 201. DEFINITIONS.

    In this title--
            (1) "Administration" and "Administrator" refer to the Small Business Administration and its Administrator;
            (2) "region of the Administration" is defined in section 3(u) of the Small Business Act;
            (3) "small business concern" is defined in section 3 of the Small Business Act.

SEC. 202. PROMOTION OF EXPORTING.

    Amendment to Section 22(c)(11) of the Small Business Act to include conducting outreach events in each State promoting exporting for small businesses. SEC. 203. SMALL BUSINESS EXPORT MATCHMAKING PILOT PROGRAM. The Administrator will establish a pilot program to conduct matchmaking events in each region to connect small businesses with potential foreign buyers. At least 1 event per region per year will be held, and events may be coordinated with outreach events. The program will end on September 30, 2015. SEC. 204 amends the Small Business Act to prioritize educating small businesses on Federal export control regulations. SEC. 205 establishes a Small Business Inter-Agency Task Force on Export Financing. SEC. 205 establishes a Small Business Inter-Agency Task Force on Export Financing to review and improve Federal export finance programs for small businesses and coordinate government activities to assist small businesses in exporting. The Secretary of Commerce will provide State resource guides on Export.gov, detailing export promotion and financing resources in each State, including State agencies, district export councils, and trade associations.
